org.obrel.core

Class Relation<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
      • org.obrel.core.SerializableRelatedObject
        • org.obrel.core.Relation<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, Relatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DirectRelation, RelationWrapper, TransformedRelation

    public abstract class Relation<T>
extends SerializableRelatedObject
    This is the abstract base class for relations from a certain origin object to a target object. Relations are related objects themselves so that certain relation type implementations can associate data with relation instances by using relations recursively. The generic type parameter defines the type of the target object.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • addUpdateListener

        public void addUpdateListener(EventHandler<RelationEvent<T>> rListener)
        Adds a listener to update events of this particular relation. This method provides a type-safe interface for adding relation event listeners to the relation with the type ListenerTypes.RELATION_UPDATE_LISTENERS. To remove a listener that relation can be modified directly because type safety is not needed then.
        Parameters:
        rListener - The relation event listener to add

      • aliasAs

        public final Relation<T> aliasAs(RelationType<T> rAliasType,
                                 Relatable rInParent)
        Creates an alias with the same datatype as the relation type of this relation. This is achieved by using an identity function as the conversion.
        See Also:
        #viewAs(RelationType, RelatedObject)

      • aliasAs

        public final <A> Relation<A> aliasAs(RelationType<A> rAliasType,
                                     Relatable rInParent,
                                     InvertibleFunction<T,A> fAliasConversion)
        Creates an alias for this relation with another relation type in a certain related object. Relation aliases refer directly to the original relation's target. Therefore changes to the original relation will be visible in it's aliases too. If the original relation is deleted all it's aliases will be deleted too. On the other hand deleting an alias won't effect neither the original relation nor any other alias.

        The parent of the alias can be any related object, it doesn't need to be the same parent object of the original relation. The alias relation type can be different from the type of this relation. The given conversion function must be invertible and convert from original target value to the datatype of the alias relation type and vice versa. This conversion will be performed on each read or write access to the relation.

        To create a read-only alias the method #viewAs(RelationType, RelatedObject) can be used instead.

        Parameters:
        rAliasType - The relation type of the relation alias
        rInParent - The parent object to add the relation alias to
        fAliasConversion - A conversion function that produces the target value of the alias and can be inverted for the setting of new targets
        Returns:
        The alias relation

      • annotate

        public final Relation<T> annotate(RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> rAnnotationType)
        A convenience method to set boolean annotations to TRUE.
        See Also:
        annotate(RelationType, Object)

      • annotate

        public final <V> Relation<T> annotate(RelationType<V> rAnnotationType,
                                      V rValue)
        Creates an annotation on this relation with a certain relation type and value. Annotations are meta-relations that provide additional information about relations. This method is just a semantic variant of the relatable method Relatable.set(RelationType, Object). The only difference is that it returns the relation instance instead of the created (meta-) relation to allow the concatenation of annotation calls.

        Like all other relations annotations can be queried through the get methods that relations inherit from RelatedObject. But in some cases it may also make sense to set meta-information on the relation type instead of the relation. To support this relations have additional methods like hasAnnotation(RelationType) that first check the relation for annotations and if not found also the relation type.

        Parameters:
        rAnnotationType - The relation type of the annotation
        rValue - The annotation value
        Returns:
        Returns this instance to allow concatenation of annotation setting

      • equals

        public final boolean equals(java.lang.Object rObject)
        Implements the equality test for relations. Subclasses must implement the abstract method dataEqual(Relation).
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        See Also:
        Object.equals(Object)

      • getAnnotation

        public final <V> V getAnnotation(RelationType<V> rAnnotationType)
        Returns the value of an annotation of this relation or it's type. Annotations are meta-informations on relations or their type. This is a convenience method to retrieve annotations from either this relation or from it's type in which the relation has precedence before the type. See annotate(RelationType, Object) for more information about annotations.
        Parameters:
        rAnnotationType - The annotation type
        Returns:
        The annotation value from either this relation or from it's type; will be NULL if no such annotation is available

      • getType

        public final RelationType<T> getType()
        Returns the relation's type.
        Returns:
        The type of this relation

      • hasAnnotation

        public final boolean hasAnnotation(RelationType<?> rAnnotationType)
        Checks whether this relation or it's type have been annotated with a certain relation type. Annotations are meta-informations on relations or their type. This method provides a convenience check for both this relation and it's type for a certain annotation in which the relation has precedence before the type. See annotate(RelationType, Object) for more information about annotations.
        Parameters:
        rAnnotationType - The annotation type
        Returns:
        TRUE if either this relation or it's type have an annotation with the given type

      • hasFlagAnnotation

        public final boolean hasFlagAnnotation(RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> rAnnotationType)
        A convenience method to check annotations that have a boolean value. For details see method getAnnotation(RelationType).
        Parameters:
        rAnnotationType - The annotation type
        Returns:
        TRUE if the flag is set on either this relation or it's relation type

        public final int hashCode()
        Overrides:

      • immutable

        public void immutable()
        Sets this relation to be immutable and tries to apply the immutable state recursively to the relation's target object. For this it checks whether the target either implements the Immutability interface or, if it is a Relatable object, sets the MetaTypes.IMMUTABLE flag. Else if the target is a collection or a map it will be wrapped in a corresponding unmodifiable instance.

      • onChange

        public EventHandler<RelationEvent<T>> onChange(java.util.function.Consumer<T> fChangeHandler)
        Adds an event listener for changes of this relation's target. Other than with onUpdate(Consumer) change listeners are only notified if the target value has changed according to it's equals() method. This method is a simplified form of addUpdateListener(EventHandler) for listeners that are only interested in UPDATE events and don't need the full event data.
        Parameters:
        fChangeHandler - The handler for update events
        Returns:
        The registered event handler (needed for de-registration of the event listener)

      • onUpdate

        public EventHandler<RelationEvent<T>> onUpdate(java.util.function.Consumer<T> fUpdateHandler)
        Adds an event listener for updates of this relation's target. This listener will be notified of any update event for the relation target, whether it has really changed or not. To be notified of changes only the method onChange(Consumer) can be used instead. This method is a simplified form of addUpdateListener(EventHandler) for listeners that are only interested in UPDATE events and don't need the full event data.
        Parameters:
        fUpdateHandler - The handler for update events
        Returns:
        The registered event handler (needed for de-registration of the event listener)

      • viewAs

        public final Relation<T> viewAs(RelationType<? super T> rViewType,
                                Relatable rInParent)
        Creates a view with the same datatype as the relation type of this relation. This is achieved by using an identity function as the conversion.
        See Also:
        #viewAs(RelationType, RelatedObject)

      • viewAs

        public final <V> Relation<V> viewAs(RelationType<V> rViewType,
                                    Relatable rInParent,
                                    Function<T,V> fViewConversion)
        Creates a view for this relation with another relation type. Like aliases created with #aliasAs(RelationType, RelatedObject) views refer directly to the original relation's target but are always readonly so that modifications of the relation can only be performed through the original relation. The parent of the view can be any related object, it doesn't need to be the same parent object of the original relation.

        The view relation type can be different from the type of this relation. The given conversion function must convert the original target value to the datatype of the view relation type. This conversion will be performed on each read access to the relation.

        Parameters:
        rViewType - The relation type of the relation view
        rInParent - The parent object to add the relation view to
        fViewConversion - A conversion function that produces the target value of the view
        Returns:
        The view relation

      • removed

        protected void removed()
        Will be invoked after a relation has been removed from it's parent Relatable. The default implementation does nothing.
